in the surgeon general's famous report that used what is often called either the surgeon general's or the Bradford Hill criteria that was the report in which active cigarette smoking was associated with lung cancer and with coronary disease and they made two very important points in the criteria that they used one was an entity called the consistency of the association that meant

that in the various different reports you were looking at there ought to be very few or no contradictions and in fact in the association between active smoking and lung cancer 27 out of 29 so-called retrospective studies and all seven of seven prospective studies all went in exactly the same direction

the SEC hearing that was set up that surgeon general's committee or Bradford Hill criteria if you want to call it that dealt with the strength of the association they ask for a so-called dose-response relationship and they wanted High relative risk ratios from lung cancer it turned out that those risk ratios were about 9 to 10 in average smokers and more than 20 in heavy smokers it is the demand for

a high risk ratios that has made various distinguished scientists and epidemiologist such as Ernst winter one of the first people to document the original association between Act of smoking and lung cancer that have made them say for a risk ratio to be meaningful it can't be trivially hi it's got to be well above to preferably above three

and the reason for asking risk ratios that are 3 and above and certainly much higher than two is that there is so many ways in which different kinds of biases can get into epidemiologic data that you can get a risk ratio of two just in some instances if one person has been misdiagnosed
so the usual demands for a high risk ratios is that you try to get them above three to be confident of things and certainly well above too

done there doesn't seem to have been an absolutely full deck of everything that was there the problem of the accuracy of identification of exposure is one of the fundamental scientific lesions in all epidemiologic studies when you use the so-called case control technique that was used in most of the EPA studies and you then interrogate backward to ask people about exposure

when they know what you're looking for and when the interviewer knows what you're looking for you've got to take extreme precautions to avoid bias in identifying that my colleagues and I when we do case control studies set up a whole bunch of decoy hypotheses we try to Blind our interviewers to knowing who was a case in control we even try to Blind the patients to knowing whether they were occasion control in the particular study we go
all kinds of precautions to avoid that sort of bias and as far as I know no such precautions were used in any of the basic studies that the EPA collected

I'm always mindful of a study done by dr. Walters Spitzer a professor of epidemiology in health admit Gil that he did in Alberta's some years ago on the issue of symptoms that are unaccompanied by object of evidence there had been for many years in the province of Alberta Canada complaints about Sour gas whose fumes

from a nearby mine we're coming into that community and for a great many years there have been debates and claims that these our exposure to the sour gas was causing birth defects cancers and so on and so forth and finally after about 10 years of claims counterclaims battles not unlike what we have been observing in this issue the province of

Alberta funded a large-scale study that water Spitzer ran it was eventually published under the title of SOB subjective fears and object data and what's pitchers group in what I believe one of the best epidemiologic studies ever done

beautiful controls blind interviewing all the scientific precautions that you would want what they found when they took those scientific precautions was that there was no excess of birth defects there was no excess of cancer there was no excess of any disease that could be objectively identified there was an excess of subjective complaints

that were present in people in that Community where the sour gas had been highly heralded as an evil that were not found in a control Community where the same alleged exposure had not been heralded as an evil and where the members of the community did not have all those symptoms so with respect is some of these symptomatic studies I won't deny what they have found but I would love to see some studies done

where there's object of interviewing where there is careful ascertainment of just what is wrong not just simply fill out a questionnaire and process it through the computer and the last comment that I want to make

really Echo something that I believe several of the congressman of already said and that is it decisions for Public Policy ought to depend on the goals of public policy if we as a nation want to get rid of cigarette smoking as a matter of public policy let's make that decision as a matter of public policy but that the scientific evidence used in public policy ought to depend on the standards of science

the most important probably are the relationship between Act of smoking and passive smoking and the relationship of spousal exposure to population explosion and for my view given the very small effect that's been detected some fans and uncertainties like this ought to be especially worrisome

position to some degree so when is ETS no longer ets a related question is whether there's a difference in health risk associated with a brief exposure to a high concentration BTS versus a long chronic exposure to a low concentration of ETS and should be noted that most common measures of exposure Airborne nicotine cotinine in urine generally don't detect those kinds of temporal effects

now my personal bias is that ETS at some level of exposure is a human carcinogen but I do not do not believe that the EPA study proves that and I can't prove that and therefore particularly in view of the EPA study it is not possible at this stage to classifying ETS has a known human carcinogen if the epidemiological findings on the other hand of spousal exposure are deemed to be correct and significant than ETS can be classified as a known human carcinogen but ETS
